0: Global oil markets will need to traverse myriad challenges in the medium term as structural shifts reshape oil demand and trade flows, while rising oil supplies could potentially weigh on prices through the end of the decade.
1: Divergent regional economic trajectories and the accelerating deployment of clean and energy saving technologies are combining to progressively slow the pace of oil demand growth, with a plateau emerging in the final years of our forecast, which runs to 2030.
2: Emerging economies in Asia, particularly China and India, account for all of global demand growth.
3: By contrast, oil demand in advanced economies falls sharply.
4: Rising world oil supplies, led by non OPEC+ producers, are expected to surpass forecast demand from 2025 onwards.
5: Mirroring demand’s break with long term trends, a front loaded build in oil production capacity is forecast to lose momentum and swing into contraction towards the end of our medium term outlook.
6: A surge in natural gas liquids  and condensates will account for 45% of new capacity increases over the forecast period.
7: In a major shift in strategy, Saudi Arabia has put on hold its planned crude oil capacity increase and will now focus on expanding natural gas liquids and condensates, which aligns with its efforts to boost domestic gas supply.
8: It may also reflect an acknowledgment of the rapidly building surplus in global crude oil production capacity.
9: The rise of petrochemicals as the main pillar of global demand growth largely tracks the substantial increase in global supply of NGLs, which are instrumental in their production.
10: At the same time, these changes will also create new challenges for refiners as demand for refined products is displaced by non refined products such as NGLs and biofuels.
11: Non refined fuels are set to capture a staggering three quarters of projected global demand growth over the 2023 2030 period.
12: Moreover, refiners will need to reconfigure their product slates to meet divergent trends for distillates amid reduced consumption as the energy transition accelerates.
13: This is especially the case in road transport fuels as EVs rapidly increase their market share.
14: Amid all these structural changes to supply and demand patterns, the global oil market outlook faces further uncertainties from weaker macroeconomic expectations, new government policies and regulations to fast track the energy transition, and an unprecedented level of investment to scale up more efficient technologies.
15: While the challenges are formidable, the industry has consistently proved its adaptability to dramatic supply and demand changes, including from the energy crisis brought on by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the Covid 19 pandemic before that.
16: A ramping up of world oil production capacity, led by the United States and other producers in the Americas, is expected to outstrip demand growth over the 2023 2030 forecast period and inflate the world’s spare capacity cushion to levels that are unprecedented, barring the Covid 19 period.
17: Total supply capacity rises by 6 mb/d to nearly 113,8 mb/d by 2030, a staggering 8 mb/d above projected global demand of 105,4 mb/d.
18: Such a massive cushion could upend the current OPEC+ market management strategy aimed at supporting prices.
19: For now, the producer alliance has laid out a roadmap for unwinding extra voluntary cuts of up to 2,2 mb/d from Q4 2024 to Q3 2025.
20: But this outlook is subject to their caveat that the production increases can be paused or reversed depending on market conditions.
21: A lower price environment would ultimately challenge the US shale industry, traditionally the fastest respondent to changing market circumstances.
22: How the industry will adapt and adjust to the new supply landscape will have wide ranging consequences for producers and consumers globally through the remainder of the decade and beyond.
23: Based on today’s market conditions and policies, global oil demand will level off at around 106 mb/d towards the end of the decade amid the accelerating transition to clean energy technologies.
24: Surging EV sales and continued efficiency improvements of vehicles, and the substitution of oil with renewables or gas in the power sector, will significantly curb oil use in road transport and electricity generation.
25: Total oil demand is nevertheless forecast to rise by 3,2 mb/d between 2023 and 2030, supported by increased use of jet fuel and feedstocks from the booming petrochemical sector.
26: Indeed, consumption of naphtha, liquified petroleum gas  and ethane will climb by 3,7 mb/d over the forecast period, fuelled also by growth in LPG use for clean cooking.
27: Growth will be dominated by Asian economies, especially India and China, as oil demand’s pivot to emerging markets continues.
28: Demand from the two Asian economic powerhouses will develop in very different ways, however.
29: In China, growth is set to be driven by the petrochemical sector as rapid deployment of clean energy technologies and massive infrastructure investments in high speed rail blunt demand for transport fuels.
30: In India, transport fuels will defy the global trend, rising sharply.
31: Significant gains will also come from other emerging and developing economies in Asia.
32: By contrast, demand in advanced economies will continue its decades long decline, falling from 45,7 mb/d in 2023 to 42,7 mb/d by 2030.
33: Apart from during the pandemic, the last time demand was this low was in 1991.
34: Over that same time period, oil demand from emerging and developing economies will have increased by a factor of 2,5.
35: In line with the ascendancy of petrochemicals as the anchor of global oil demand growth, 45% of the supply capacity increase over the forecast period comes from NGLs and condensates.
36: While Saudi Arabia has shelved its planned crude capacity increase from 12 mb/d to 13 mb/d, its development of the massive Jafurah gas field will move ahead.
37: This will result in a substantial ramping up of gas liquids output of almost 1 mb/d by 2030, volumes that are not subject to OPEC+ quotas.
38: Strong gains in US NGLs are also expected.
39: Total NGLs and condensates are projected to rise by 2,7 mb/d from 2023 to 2030.
40: By comparison, crude oil production capacity is forecast to increase by 2,6 mb/d over the same period, while biofuels account for 620 kb/d of the 6 mb/d total.
41: Non OPEC+ producers will continue to lead the capacity build, accounting for 4,6 mb/d, or 76% of the net increase.
42: The United States alone makes up 2,1 mb/d of the non OPEC+ gains, while Brazil, Guyana, Canada and Argentina contribute a further 2,7 mb/d.
43: As the sanctioned project queue fizzles out towards the end of our forecast, growth stalls in the United States and Canada while Brazil and Guyana shift into decline based on current plans.
44: However, should companies swiftly approve additional projects that are already on the drawing board, an incremental 1,3 mb/d of non OPEC+ capacity could become operational by 2030.
45: Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Iraq lead a 1,4 mb/d rise in OPEC+ oil capacity as African and Asian members post declines.
46: The UAE and Iraq are raising crude oil capacity while Saudi Arabia is poised for a significant increase NGL and condensates supply.
47: Capacity in Russia is expected to show only a marginal decline despite international sanctions as the giant Vostok project ramps up, helping to offset losses at mature oil fields.
48: The boost in supply follows a steady increase in upstream investments.
49: Global upstream capital expenditures rose by 13% to an eight year high of USD 538 billion in 2023 and are on track to increase by another 7% this year.
50: Global refining capacity is forecast to rise by 3,3 mb/d from 2023 to 2030, well below historical trends.
51: Even with the moderate expansion in capacity, the increase outpaces the call on refined products over the period.
52: Refiners will need to progressively modify their product output to meet divergent trends for distillates as gasoline demand falls amid an increase in the market share of electric vehicles while jet fuel consumption rises.
53: In addition, non refined fuels such as NGLs and biofuels further undermine demand for refined product supplies and the need for additional refining capacity.
54: Non refined fuel products are set to capture more than 75% of projected demand growth over the 2023 2030 period.
55: This significant rise in non refinery product supplies will add pressure on operating rates and refinery profitability, especially in mature demand centres.
56: That raises the prospect of further capacity closures by the end of the decade.
57: Capacity growth will remain concentrated in Asia, most notably in China and India, but post 2027 there are signs of expansions slowing.
58: Global oil trade will continue to be dictated by Asia’s growing structural shortfall in crude and product supply and the expanding surplus of crude, NGLs and products in the Atlantic Basin.
59: Rising non OPEC+ crude supply, in tandem with sanctions on Russian crude exports and OPEC+ voluntary cuts, will push higher volumes from the Atlantic Basin to East of Suez over the outlook period.
60: The loss of medium sour crudes from the Middle East amid OPEC+ cuts is partially offset by rising supplies from Brazil, Guyana and Canada.
61: Asian markets have been opened in earnest to Canadian crude through the expanded Trans Mountain pipeline to the Pacific Coast.
62: Light sweet US crude oil will increasingly move to Europe and Africa as well as to India and other Asian refiners.
63: As the dominant centre of oil product demand growth, Asia will attract a greater share of product supply from the broader region, notably from the Middle East.
64: Supplies from Russia, which are subject to sanctions in much of the Atlantic Basin, will continue to head eastward, although Africa and Latin America may also boost imports over time.
65: Europe’s shortfall in diesel and jet fuel supply, plus North America’s need for jet fuel imports, will focus global competition most keenly in the middle distillate markets.
66: Oil demand growth will slow progressively over the rest of the decade.
67: The post pandemic rebound has faded, macroeconomic drivers remain weak and the accelerating deployment of clean energy technologies weighs heavily on key sectors and regions.
68: Growth decelerates from 2,1 mb/d in 2023, with demand plateauing at 105,6 mb/d by 2029, and then shifting into a narrow contraction in the final year of our medium term outlook.
69: This slow erosion in global demand growth results in a net increase of 3,2 mb/d during the 2023 2030 forecast period.
70: Growth will be dominated by non OECD Asian economies, especially India and China, as oil demand’s decades long pivot to emerging markets continues.
71: Total non OECD demand is forecast to rise 6,1 mb/d by 2030.
72: While road transport use will ease as vehicle electrification gathers pace, significant potential remains for incremental jet fuel and petrochemical feedstock consumption.
73: By contrast, the OECD, led by Europe and Americas, will post a sharp decline of 2,9 mb/d over the forecast period.
74: Shifting patterns of use, with most growth taking place in non combustion applications like petrochemicals and a higher share of biofuels, mean that CO2 emissions from oil use could peak as early as 2026.
75: The global economy has so far proved resilient during the unprecedented central bank interest rate hikes of 2022 2023 that coincided with the end to the post Covid economic  rebound.
76: These campaigns can be considered largely successful in that consumer inflation, although still above target, has eased considerably, while economic activity remained mostly robust.
77: Still, the long term impact of this bout of monetary tightening is undetermined, especially in developed countries.
78: Here, GDP growth remains subpar at 1 to 2% over the forecast period amid lacklustre manufacturing and trade, and tight credit conditions.
79: On a global level, this is partly counterbalanced by robust growth in non OECD economies, averaging 4% in India and other Asian countries.
80: While China’s growth will also settle around this level, this marks a sharp deceleration from the country’s overleveraged 1990 2010 boom years, with the protracted property slump weighing on economic sentiment.
81: Consequently, global GDP growth is set to remain around half a percent below its 2010s pre pandemic trend at an average annual rate of 3% over the forecasting period.
82: Now that the pandemic period  has concluded
83: , economic fundamentals are set to regain their traditional role as main drivers of oil demand, albeit only briefly.
84: Global oil demand growth of about 1 mb/d in 2024 and 2025 is roughly in line with the level implied by GDP growth.
85: However, this long established correlation is set to break down in subsequent years.
86: Oil consumption effectively decouples from GDP from 2026 onwards, as substitution away from oil in transport and power generation pushes oil demand growth towards zero, and eventually into decline.
87: The substitution effect is especially prominent in transport , the mainstay of oil demand , with road fuel demand already plateauing this year, and total transport close behind.
88: EV sales are set to continue their stellar growth trajectory, resulting in significant fuel savings.
89: This will displace 6 mb/d of gasoline and diesel demand by 2030, with a further contribution from improving fuel economies.
90: Post pandemic changes in consumer mobility behaviour contribute a further 1 mb/d in transport fuel savings as remote and hybrid work are now well established.
91: The picture for public transport use is more mixed , city mass transit ridership has not yet regained 2019 levels in developed countries, partly because consumers shifted to car journeys.
92: Conversely, in China public transport rebounded to pre Covid levels in the immediate aftermath of the country’s reopening, while highway passenger volumes remain at around half of 2019 levels, according to data reported by China’s National Bureau of Statistics .
93: The displacement of oil used in electricity generation will also play a major role in shifting global demand to a plateau.
94: In particular, Saudi Arabia has plans that would see about 1 mb/d cut from direct crude, fuel oil and gasoil use in power plants by 2030.
95: A large increase in utilisation of domestic gas and renewable resources would enable this.
96: Iraq is also expected to reduce oil burn in power plants, albeit on a smaller scale.
97: Long distance transport such as aviation and marine shipping, where demand is less amenable to direct substitution, will continue to post growth.
98: However, here fuel efficiencies are increasingly slowing demand gains.
99: Global flight activity regained pre pandemic levels over the course of 2023, but at present jet/kerosene use remains about 5% below 2019 levels.
100: Consumption is not expected to surpass pre Covid levels until 2027, with healthy underlying demand for air travel counterbalanced by major strides in aircraft fuel efficiencies.
101: Along the same line, efficiencies related to regulations by the International Maritime Organization  are set to gradually erode consumption of marine fuels.
102: In a marked contrast to the increasingly anaemic gains in transport fuels, petrochemical feedstocks will be the cornerstones of overall growth, as global polymer and synthetic fibre consumption steadily rises.
103: Naphtha and LPG/ethane use will climb by a combined 3,7 mb/d over the forecast period.
104: Four fifths of this increment will be for deliveries to petrochemical plants, with growth in LPG demand for clean cooking and other domestic applications also playing a major role.
105: Especially strong growth for LPG/ethane use , up by 2,5 mb/d between 2023 and 2030 , reflects substantial increases in new NGL supply, notably from the United States and major Middle Eastern producers.
106: China will continue to dominate growth in petrochemicals and gains of 1,4 mb/d in feedstock products will be close to the country’s overall increase to 2030.
107: On the other hand, rapid deployment of clean energy technologies will balance strong underlying mobility growth.
108: Climbing EV sales and the impacts of infrastructure investments such as high speed rail have blunted gasoline demand growth and China’s use of the fuel is set to peak by 2025.
109: In India transport fuels will defy the global trend and increase significantly.
110: Indian demand is expected to rise by 1,3 mb/d, with growth almost equal to that of its northern neighbour.
111: Combined gains in all non OECD Asian economies other than China and India will be even larger at 1,6 mb/d.
112: Together, emerging Asian economies will be far and away the most important source of oil demand growth this decade.
114: By contrast, demand in OECD economies will continue its decades long decline.
115: In 2007, OECD demand was 50,2 mb/d and accounted for 57% of global oil use.
116: By 2019 this had fallen to 47,5 mb/d  and in 2023 deliveries averaged 45,7 mb/d .
117: By 2030, OECD consumption will drop to 42,7 mb/d, 41% of the global total.
118: Advanced economies have comparatively low GDP elasticities and can expect more limited economic growth.
119: In general, they have also implemented ambitious clean energy policies.
120: As a result, OECD countries will experience the largest declines in transport fuel demand and smaller rises in jet fuel demand.
121: Increases in OECD petrochemical feedstock use will be largely confined to the United States.
122: There are various risks to our demand forecast, of which assumptions about economic growth, oil prices and the pace of EV sales are key.
123: Also, deviations for these factors are likely to be interdependent , for example, a faster pace of GDP growth is likely to be accompanied by higher oil prices and quicker EV adoption.
124: Moreover, oil’s flattish, plateauing demand profile post 2027 means that it would only take relatively minor changes in its underlying drivers to directionally shift oil’s demand trajectory.
125: For example, either a 0,3% quickening in global GDP growth, a USD 5/bbl annual decline in real oil prices or a 15% slowdown in the pace of global EV adoption would be sufficient for oil consumption to cross the narrow dividing line back from shrinkage to growth at the end of the decade.
126: Conversely, opposite shifts of the same magnitude would accelerate oil demand’s slide into contraction.
127: The global economy is still in the process of adjusting to 2022’s sea change, when major central banks launched their unprecedented battle against consumer inflation that reached 40 year highs.
128: These measures have to date resulted in a cumulative 4 5% hike in interest rates for advanced economies.
129: Whilst still inconclusive considering monetary policy’s long and variable lags, these campaigns can so far be considered largely successful, inflation has retreated from its 9 10% peak to around 3% in most developed countries.
130: Moreover, the decline has been achieved without driving the global economy into recession, amid notably firm labour markets and resilient consumer spending.
131: However, the final stage of this push has proved challenging, with inflation remaining stubbornly above its target of 2%, by around 1 2%.
132: Until this “last mile” has been completed, the hoped for soft landing for the global economy, accompanied by a return to monetary easing, may prove elusive.
133: In this context, breakeven inflation rates derived from bond markets price annual US inflation at around 2,4% at a five year horizon.
134: Regardless, higher interest rates and tighter credit mean that global economic growth is set to remain below its pre pandemic trend for the foreseeable future.
135: A slump in global trade weighs heavily on export dependent China and the eurozone, with both pivoting towards structurally lower expansion.
136: In this regard, the present shift towards deglobalisation does not augur well, as higher tariffs and other restrictions hamper trade and upend supply chains.
137: Sino US trade frictions, focused on technology, have become especially visible.
138: In parallel, geopolitical risks have also become more pertinent, amid wars in Ukraine and the Middle East and an increasingly tense relationship between China and some neighbouring countries.
139: Government spending has been rampant since the pandemic, with knock on effects on borrowing, interest rates and prices.
140: As outlays for programmes such as social security, health care, the green economy and defence balloon, so do fiscal deficits and government debt burdens.
141: The IMF has singled out budget deficits in the United States and China as posing significant financial stability risks
142: Global GDP growth is projected to average 3% over the 2024 2030 forecast period, about half a point lower than during the 2010s.
143: Emerging economies will remain the main drivers by far, with average 2024 2030 non OECD GDP growth more than double the OECD rate .
144: By 2030, the non OECD share of total global GDP will climb to 59%, from 55% in 2023.
145: GDP expansion in the United States will reach 2,6% in 2024 before subsiding, as higher for longer interest rates trickle down into the real economy and excess savings from the pandemic era are finally depleted.
146: Growth will average 1,7% over the remainder of the forecast period.
147: Soaring fiscal deficits  will increasingly add to price pressures and act as a drag on economic growth.
148: The eurozone will gradually emerge from the economic stagnation that began in 2022, as lower interest rates and disinflation boost real incomes and private consumption.
149: Germany will be a key engine of the modest recovery as a rebound in manufacturing lifts GDP growth to 1,3% in 2025 after two years of little growth and will remain around that level thereafter.
150: Japan’s GDP will expand by 0,5% on average between 2024 and 2030, the lowest of any major economy as an ageing population and a shrinking labour force weigh on productivity and depress potential growth.
151: China’s economy continues to battle formidable headwinds such as a shrinking population, a protracted real estate slump now in its third year, industrial overcapacity, heavily indebted local governments and a nascent deflationary spiral amid soft domestic demand.
152: Baseline trend growth will fall below 4% in 2026 and remain there to the end of our forecast period.
153: Whilst reasonably firm in global terms, this is around half of the country’s pre pandemic trend.
154: India’s GDP growth will remain by far the strongest among major economies, averaging 6,5% over the forecast period due to structural tailwinds such as benign demographics, a burgeoning middle class, and accelerating urbanisation and industrialisation.
155: Oil demand will grow at a relatively fast rate as the energy intensity of the country’s economy picks up from a low base.
156: Assumptions about GDP growth and its impact on oil demand are a key component of our demand estimates.
157: The average GDP elasticity of global oil demand is about 0,3 for OECD and 0,6 for non OECD, reflecting the greater oil intensity of emerging markets.
158: Additionally, expectations of future oil prices are paramount for demand estimates, with forecasts sensitive to both the absolute price level and sequential price changes over the outlook period.
159: Oil prices used for the modelling are based on an average 2025 Brent crude price of about USD 79/bbl , which is held constant in real terms over the remainder of the forecasting period.
160: In addition to this base case, we have considered alternative high and low price Scenarios.
161: Assumes oil prices increase by 2,5% in real terms per annum, in line with their long term historical pattern.
162: Estimates of future spot prices are based on the ICE Brent forward curve .
163: These prices are then discounted to real terms.
164: The high price scenario would curtail 2030 global oil demand by 650 kb/d.
165: However, this would not cause demand to peak earlier.
166: Conversely, the low price scenario would lift oil consumption by 1,1 mb/d at the end of the forecasting period, eliminating the current 2029 peak.
167: The impact of changes in oil prices on oil demand is roughly similar in OECD and non OECD economies, despite non OECD oil consumption being, at least in theory, more sensitive to changes in oil prices.
168: Developing economies tend to be more oil intensive with their output gravitating towards agriculture and heavy industry.
169: Also, energy ranks high in developing country Consumer Price Index  baskets, with poorer households spending a larger share of their income on basic goods.
170: In theory, this results in higher oil demand price elasticities, as a price increase will be more keenly felt in developing countries.
171: However, these higher theoretical elasticities for lower income countries are not at all clear in reality.
172: This is because the market price mechanism whereby open market oil prices are converted into retail prices is less straightforward in poorer countries, being heavily mediated by their governments through price controls and subsidies.
173: These controls contribute to retail prices that are, as a rule, much lower in developing countries and closer to global wholesale market levels.
174: In this regard, poorer countries contrast sharply with OECD countries where elevated fuel taxes inflate retail prices.
175: More importantly, the prevalence of price controls in non OECD economies results in a weak pass through of market oil prices into pump prices.
176: A prime example is India, where retail prices have remained virtually unchanged since mid 2022.
177: Retail pump prices in petrostates such as Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Kuwait and Qatar have also been fixed for years, according to data from GlobalPetrolPrices.
178: Statistically, the disparity is reflected in the demand weighted correlation between global gasoline prices and local currency retail pump prices.
179: From January 2021 to February 2024, this correlation was only 58% for non OECD countries, compared to 81% for OECD countries.
180: The equivalent percentages for diesel were 64% and 84%, respectively.
181: Global electric car sales continue to display stellar growth.
182: According to the IEA’s Global Electric Vehicle Outlook 2024, sales could reach around 17 million in 2024, increasing from 14 million in 2023, with EVs accounting for nearly one in five cars sold globally.
183: This ascent is set to persist, with total sales projected to reach 40 million in 2030, when almost one in two new cars will be an EV.
184: This will displace around 6 mb/d of road fuels demand by the end of our forecast period.
185: The EV phenomenon remains primarily a Chinese one.
186: In 2023 the majority of EV sales were in China , with Europe  and the United States  accounting for the bulk of sales elsewhere.
187: This dominance is set to continue , almost one in three cars on the roads in China by 2030 is expected to be electric, compared to almost one in five in both the United States and the European Union.
188: Along the same lines, more than half of all EVs sold globally were produced by Chinese carmakers, compared to only 10% for internal combustion engine  cars.
189: The environment for EVs has become more challenging in Western countries of late amid the partial phasing out of tax breaks and subsidies, with unsold cars piling up at car dealership lots.
190: In contrast to China’s mass market adoption, EVs remain a comparatively niche product in developed economies, experiencing difficulty broadening their appeal beyond relatively prosperous, environmentally concerned urban motorists.
191: High sticker prices, the lack of an adequate charging infrastructure and collapsing second hand values act as deterrents to less affluent buyers.
192: At the same time, trade frictions between China and the west are building due to cheap EVs from China rapidly gaining market share, crowding out higher cost Western carmakers.
193: This has prompted accusations that, backed by disproportionate government aid, China is exporting its structural overcapacity.
194: The May 2024 decision by the Biden Administration to quadruple tariffs on Chinese EVs is a case in point.
195: The European Union was also conducting an anti dumping investigation into Chinese EVs at the time of writing.
196: Despite these headwinds, we expect EV growth to continue the acceleration of recent years, with oil demand savings advancing as more cars enter the fleet.
197: This increase will be underpinned by ambitious zero emissions targets, ongoing industrial policy support and steadily falling prices , parity with ICE cars could be attained by 2030 for most models outside of China.
198: Still, it is worth emphasising that our forecast is highly dependent on EV ownership extending beyond early adopters and finding mass market acceptance in Western economies.
199: While China remains the key driver of growth, sales will become less concentrated both geographically  and in terms of fuels, with diesel gaining in relative importance.
200: EVs are set to avoid an extra annual 1 mb/d of road fuels demand in 2029 and 2030, for a cumulative displacement of 6,1 mb/d, marking a sixfold increase versus 2023.
201: Of this amount, 4,7 mb/d will be in gasoline and 1,4 mb/d in diesel.
202: For the latter fuel, commercial and freight use will account for around 1 mb/d of savings, while in regional terms Europe will be responsible for the lion’s share at 630 kb/d, outstripping the continent’s gasoline savings of 530 kb/d.
203: Efficiency improvements will assume increased importance over the forecast period in all transport segments, including road, maritime and aviation.
204: Total efficiency gains are expected to reduce oil demand growth by 4,7 mb/d from 2023 to 2030, with the majority of savings in OECD road fuels amid stricter environmental regulations in Europe and the United States.
205: The European Union adopted new vehicle carbon dioxide  standards in March 2023, requiring a 55% reduction in emissions of new cars by 2030 versus 2021.
206: The new rule released by the United States Environmental Protection Agency  in March 2024 is projected to cut CO2 emissions from light duty vehicles by nearly 50% in 2032 from 2026, to 85 grammes of CO2 per mile.
207: Carmakers have been given a three year extension to 2030 to reduce tailpipe emissions amid a “technology neutral” approach.
208: Besides fully electric vehicles, compliance can be attained by producing a range of “cleaner” cars, including gas powered cars, hybrid EVs, and plug in hybrids.
209: Much of these efficiency gains are being offset by a shift towards larger conventional cars, which will support road fuel demand in the medium term.
210: To a considerable extent, improvements in engine efficiency have enabled more widespread ownership of larger vehicles, as fuel cost savings increase affordability, in line with the Jevons Paradox.
211: In some cases, carmakers also use larger bodies for hybrid vehicles, where additional equipment requires more space.
212: This increase in size may also be visible within the EV segment.
213: As a result of efficiency improvements and EVs crowding out ICE cars, road fuels, especially gasoline, would become more readily available and comparatively lower in cost.
214: Price elastic consumers, especially in emerging market countries, would be the main beneficiaries of a rebound effect on demand, partly offsetting direct global fuel savings due to efficiencies and greater EV use.
215: Four years after the Covid 19 pandemic brought unprecedented disruptions to everyday life, people’s daily routines have overwhelmingly returned to normal.
216: In parallel, oil demand growth has reverted to its former underlying behavioural drivers, with traditional economic factors replacing public health restrictions.
217: A key exception in this regard is in corporate life, where mobility patterns have been transformed due to a persistent shift to remote and hybrid work.
218: After cratering during H1 2020, office attendance initially rebounded sharply as social distancing measures were relaxed.
219: However, this recovery has stalled since 2022, with remote and hybrid work in developed economies stabilising at permanently higher levels.
220: In 2023, full time employees in America worked from home  1,4 days per week on average according to the Global Survey of Working Arrangements, a fivefold increase versus 2019.
221: In this context, the United States is emblematic of a group of advanced economies, predominantly in the Anglosphere, for example, Canada  and the United Kingdom, where WFH has effectively become part of the new normal.
222: The custom has advanced less in other developed economies, with an average 0,8 days per week worked remotely in mainland European countries, and 0,7 days in Asia.
223: Also, there are large differences within countries across age groups, incomes and industries.
224: WFH is most common among higher paid, higher educated workers and concentrated in knowledge intensive sectors such as finance and information technology, where work can be more easily performed remotely.
225: These technologically adept employees also tend to be younger.
226: Other factors contribute to the appeal of WFH , US workers tend to have longer and more expensive commutes as well as bigger homes, incentivising remote work.
227: WFH’s future, beyond the stabilisation of recent years, is uncertain.
228: Its impact on productivity is still hotly debated, with some employers tightening their rules and demanding that remote staff return to their desks at least some of the time.
229: A recent slowdown in hiring in finance and tech may strengthen their hand.
230: Conversely, lawmakers in several nations have passed legislation promoting the right to flexible work arrangements or proposed doing so.
231: Also, technological innovation in video conferencing may enhance the quality and prevalence of virtual meetings.
232: In the United States, WFH has accelerated the long term decoupling between road fuel demand and the size of the economy.
233: Gasoline consumption has been lagging key macroeconomic indicators for decades, as driving mobility gradually moved towards saturation.
234: In 2023, total vehicle miles travelled  were almost the same as in 2019, although GDP had increased by 8%.
235: Widening the gap further is that fuel demand has also lagged mobility , US gasoline deliveries were 4% lower over this period, as more efficient car engines and an expanding EV fleet curtailed demand.
236: Partially counteracting WFH’s negative effects on gasoline demand since 2020 was a switch from public transport to car journeys, as health risk averse travellers avoided public transit and quieter roads in some regions made driving easier.
237: While mass transit ridership rebounded strongly in 2022 and 2023, passenger volumes in most developed economies remain short of 2019 levels.
238: Public transport use has fallen in major US and UK cities due to remote working.
239: According to the Metropolitan Transport Authority, ridership on the New York subway averaged 68% of pre pandemic traffic in 2023.
240: Data from Transport for London  paint a similar picture, with bus and metro journeys at 84% of pre Covid levels by October.
241: Along the same lines, the German Federal Statistical Office reported 8% fewer bus and rail passenger journeys in 2023 than in 2019.
242: The key contrast with this lacklustre recovery has been in China, where mobility made a swift and complete comeback in the immediate aftermath of the country’s reopening.
243: Passenger volumes for rail and urban traffic had returned to pre Covid level by mid 2023, as had domestic flight activity.
244: Similarly, holiday travel rebounded to around 20% above 2019 levels during 2023’s major festivals.
245: The chief exception in this regard is long distance car travel, amid a cross modal shift to rail and air traffic, highway passenger volumes are around half of 2019 levels, according to NBS data.
246: We see the cumulative impact of post Covid remote working behavioural changes reflected in a reduction of global road fuels demand of 800 kb/d from 2023 to 2030.
247: This reduction is highly concentrated in the United States, where an estimated 500 kb/d of fuel use is being avoided
250: The pandemic wreaked large scale devastation on global air travel, rendering jet/kerosene by far the most affected among the major oil products, with demand collapsing by 41% to 4,7 mb/d during 2020.
251: In subsequent years, as lockdown restrictions eased and use rebounded, the fuel became the main driver of oil demand growth, at 1 mb/d each in 2022 and 2023.

487: To illustrate the scale of the distortion to Chinese and global demand growth we have made a simple reallocation of this ‘excess’ other products demand to gasoline and gasoil.
488: Based on the premise that reporting was relatively complete in each of 2017 and in 2024, assuming steady growth in other products in the intervening years, would imply large additional volumes allocated to fuels without changing overall demand.
489: This would also result in a much more even development in gasoline and gasoil demand during the pandemic years.
490: On this basis, gasoline usage likely peaked in 2021 and would decline slightly between 2023 and 2024, while 2023 would be the peak year for gasoil consumption.
491: This trajectory fits much better with known government restrictions and bottom up modelling of vehicle and industrial activity.
492: In particular, developments in recent years are much more in line with the rapid deployment of clean energy technologies like EVs.
493: These changes are large enough to have global implications.
494: Notably, the stronger than expected growth of gasoline in 2023 and 2024 would be blunted and global gasoil demand may well have peaked in 2022 with declines in both 2023 and 2024.
495: Although demand for both fuels narrowly surpassed pre pandemic levels in 2023, gasoline appears much closer to its turning point than might otherwise be supposed and gasoil may already been in decline.
496: World oil production capacity, led higher by the United States and other producers in the Americas, is forecast to outstrip demand growth over the 2023 2030 forecast and, barring the Covid pandemic period, inflate the world’s spare capacity cushion to unprecedented levels.
497: Total supply capacity rises by 6 mb/d to 113,8 mb/d by 2030, a staggering 8 mb/d above projected global demand of 105,4 mb/d.
498: Around 45% of the supply capacity increase over the forecast period comes from NGLs and condensates, mirroring the shift in demand to petrochemicals as the foundation of global growth.
499: Saudi Arabia and the United States will account for two thirds of the net 2,7 mb/d NGLs and condensates increase from 2023 to 2030.
500: By contrast, crude oil production capacity will expand more moderately relative to historical trends, with non OPEC+ producers providing more than 80% of the gains.
501: In a break with long term trends, the front loaded build in global oil production capacity is forecast to lose momentum and swing into contraction towards the end of our medium term outlook, with the 2024 expansion of 1,8 mb/d reversing to a drop of 280 kb/d in 2030.
502: This tracks the world’s pivot towards cleaner energy that leads to a plateau in our demand outlook by the end of the forecast and results in an effective OPEC+ spare crude oil capacity cushion of 6,8 mb/d, mostly concentrated in Saudi Arabia and the UAE. .
503: Such a massive oil production buffer could usher in a lower oil price environment, posing tough challenges for producers in the US shale patch and the OPEC+ bloc.
504: Given shale’s short cycle time frame and price reactivity, some output could be at risk .
505: Moreover, reduced requirements for OPEC+ crude may put the alliance’s market management to the test.
506: The huge amount of excess supply could also tempt some in the group to rationalise capacity plans.
507: Saudi Arabia has already taken the lead, announcing in early 2024 a suspension of its 1 mb/d crude capacity expansion.
508: At the same time, it is ramping up gas liquids, reflecting the expanding role of gas in Riyadh’s efforts to transition towards its net zero ambitions.
509: Producers outside the OPEC+ bloc  dominate medium term capacity expansion plans, adding a total of 4,6 mb/d, or 76%, of the net increase.
510: The United States alone accounts for 2,1 mb/d of the non OPEC+ gains, while Brazil, Guyana, Canada and Argentina contribute a further 2,7 mb/d.
511: As sanctioned expansions ease markedly towards the end of our forecast, growth will stall in the United States and Canada while Brazil and Guyana shift into decline based on current plans.
512: However, should companies continue to sanction additional projects that are already on the drawing board, an incremental 1,3 mb/d of non OPEC+ capacity could become operational by 2030.
513: Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Iraq lead a 1,4 mb/d rise in OPEC+ oil capacity as African and Asian members battle continuing declines.
514: The UAE and Iraq are raising crude oil capacity while Saudi Arabia is poised for a significant increase in its output of NGLs and condensates.
515: Capacity in Russia, despite international sanctions, is expected to show only a marginal decline as Moscow opens the taps at its giant Vostok project, helping to offset losses at mature oil fields.
516: Global upstream capital expenditures rose to USD 538 billion in 2023, the highest level since 2015.
517: However, in real terms, spending was still lower than in 2019 due to capital discipline and oilfield services inflation.
518: Based on 2024 guidance, spending is expected to expand by 7% y o y , a slower annual increase than the average 14% in the last three years, signalling the post Covid bounce has ended, and roughly aligned with the IEA’s Stated Policies Scenario .
519: Global oil supply to the market, as opposed to capacity, is estimated at 106,4 mb/d by 2030.
520: This represents a net increase of 4,2 mb/d from 2023 versus growth in demand of 3,2 mb/d over the same period.
521: Non OPEC+ producers in the Americas dominate the outlook, contributing 4,4 mb/d by the end of the forecast.
522: Anticipated robust non OPEC+ production throughout most of the forecast period, combined with a marked slowdown in demand, is expected to reduce the call on OPEC+ crude oil by 1,3 mb/d on average annually compared with 2024.
523: By 2030, OPEC+ oil output, including NGLs and condensates, falls by about 370 kb/d.
524: For this report, our OPEC+ oil supply outlook is based on the group’s current output policy.
525: In that case, and even with deep output cuts in place, the bloc would pump above the call on its crude oil to varying degrees from 2025 through 2030.
526: Global oil supply reaches a projected 102,9 mb/d in 2024, up 690 kb/d y o y, driven by non OPEC+ for a second year in a row.
527: That is a marked slowdown in growth of 2 mb/d in 2023.
528: From 2025 2029, annual supply gains average 550 kb/d.
529: After 2029, world oil supply is forecast to swing into contraction in line with a deceleration in oil demand growth due to, amongst other factors, the continued uptake of EVs and intensified efforts to substitute oil use in Middle East power generation.
530: The United States and Canada break fresh annual records throughout the seven year period.
531: Qatar reaches its highest ever oil output in 2027 and then climbs further on the back of its LNG expansion.
532: By contrast, Mexico posts the single largest capacity loss of any producer in the world due to underinvestment.
533: The weaker momentum in the United States and Americas from 2029 will decrease the market share of non OPEC+, allowing OPEC+ to reclaim a bit of its lost share thanks to increased liquids supply, primarily from Saudi Arabia.
534: This year, the group’s total oil market share has dropped to 48,5%, the lowest since it was formed in 2016, due to its sharp voluntary output cuts.
535: Global upstream capital expenditure  rose to USD 538 billion in 2023, the highest level since 2015 but still below 2019 levels in real terms.
536: It was the first time in nine years that investment did not move in sync with oil prices, as benchmark crude prices declined y o y.
537: Based on 2024 guidance, spending is expected to expand by 7% y o y , a slower annual increase than the average of 14% in the last three years, in nominal terms.
538: The increase in upstream investment last year was concentrated in projects executed by national oil companies  in the Middle East, China and the Americas.
539: Middle Eastern NOCs increased spending by 16% y o y in 2023, to twice the levels seen 10 years ago.
540: Saudi Aramco cancelled plans to boost its crude production capacity by 1 mb/d to 13 mb/d, reducing its total capex by USD 40 billion over the 2024 2028 period.
541: However, the Kingdom intends to focus more on natural gas and invest between USD 48 billion and USD 58 billion this year, higher than last year’s outlay of USD 49,7 billion.

566: By contrast, ExxonMobil, Chevron and ConocoPhillips continued to increase output thanks to booming US production.

583: The drop in upstream investment during the pandemic years will affect supply growth towards 2030.
584: Conventional projects sanctioned in 2019 will add an estimated 2,2 mb/d at peak, while new field start ups approved in 2020 will only add 1,5 mb/d at their maximum.

589: Large volumes were found at Stabroek and Corentyne in Guyana, and Sapakara South in Surinam.
590: In Namibia additional resources were found at Lesedi.
591: As a result, the average liquids reserves to production ratio  for the majors decreased further, dipping below 10 years.
592: Only ConocoPhillips increased its R/P ratio in 2023.
593: The divestment of Russian assets had a particularly steep impact on BP whose reserves shrunk to less than half of 2022 levels.
594: While discovered resource volumes are decreasing, companies are reallocating capital and operating expense  dollars to stymie output losses from producing fields.
595: Well capex and field direct opex levels are key drivers of decline rates.
596: And while total real capex is still below 2019 levels, real well capex is forecast at record levels of USD 300 billion.
597: Whereas facility capex has only recovered to 70% of its 2014 peak in real terms, field direct opex is at record levels when viewed in real or nominal terms.
598: SLB, rebranded from Schlumberger in 2022 and the world’s largest oilfield services company, stated in its Q1 2024 earnings call that its customers consider increased production recovery from existing assets to be critical in the coming years while current period revenue from opex driven well interventions has soared.
599: Baker Hughes’ CEO recently echoed the sentiment that the oil industry is currently either in the beginning or middle of an opex spend cycle.
600: When looking at total upstream oil spend of well capex, facility capex and field direct opex, the share of facility spend has been falling constantly, from 30% at the 2014 peak to 21% this year.
601: Meanwhile, outlays on wells have remained constant at around 40% and field direct opex spend has increased from 30% of the total to close to 40% today.
602: The rotation in capital allocation has seen the shift toward short cycle investment in shale wells and infrastructure led offshore expansions, both of which inherently have higher percentage of spend directed towards wells.
603: Additionally, there has been savings in facility spend thanks to a push towards standardization and “right sizing” offshore facilities compared to the last decade.
604: Due to the natural decline rate of oil and gas production from conventional and tight reservoirs, close to 5 mb/d of supply needs to be replaced annually to hold production flat.
605: This rate of decline is after capex and opex spend and represents a global average of close to 5%.
606: Lowering the underlying decline rate by 10 basis points  keeps 100 kb/d or a medium sized major capital project worth of production online every year.
607: The increase in opex spend since Covid 19 has helped hold replacement volumes steady even as more output comes from high decline shale barrels.
608: The growing share of light tight oil  has important implications for observed decline rates.
609: There was a 2,7 mb/d decline in production from existing US shale wells last year on a production base of 9 mb/d, while non OPEC+ conventional oil output declined by 2 mb/d on a 40 mb/d base.
610: Understanding the different segments of supply and how their decline rates evolve over the medium term is key to determining the path of supply and investment.
611: OPEC+ oil production capacity, including condensates and NGLs, is forecast to grow by a net 1,4 mb/d from 2023 through 2030 led by Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Iraq.
612: Significantly, nearly 1 mb/d of NGLs and condensates are forecast to be added in the medium term thanks largely to Saudi Arabia’s Jafurah gas field development.
613: By contrast, total OPEC+ crude capacity is projected to rise by 460 kb/d.
614: The UAE and Iraq are expected to lift crude oil capacity by a combined 1,4 mb/d by 2030.
615: Middle East producers, along with Kazakhstan, will more than offset losses from Mexico, Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa and Asia.
616: The OPEC+ alliance will see its share of world oil production ease below 50% from this year onwards as non OPEC+ countries dominate growth.
617: Angola quit the group at the start of 2024, reducing its ranks to 22 members.
618: Brazil has signed on to the OPEC+ “Charter of Cooperation” but this agreement does not subject the country to production quotas.
619: As such, Brazil remains in our non OPEC+ classification.
620: The producer alliance is meanwhile courting countries such as Guyana and Namibia as potential new recruits.
621: In 2023, total oil supplies, including condensates and NGLs, from the OPEC+ alliance fell by 370 kb/d to an average 50,7 mb/d.
622: Saudi Arabia’s production was down by more than 900 kb/d on average due to OPEC+ curbs, while some other members of the bloc with output targets posted very modest reductions.
623: The group’s overall decline was partly offset by Iran, exempt from supply quotas, which pushed output to a five year high.
624: This year could see a steeper decline of 740 kb/d for OPEC+ if existing extra voluntary curbs remain in place.
625: The producer group agreed to reduce supply in late 2022 to support the market as the economic outlook worsened.
626: Led by Saudi Arabia, additional voluntary curbs from some members in 2023 have further reduced the bloc’s output ceiling.
627: In early June, OPEC+ extended those cuts through the third quarter of 2024 and provided a timeline for unwinding them , subject to market conditions.

629: By contrast, the country’s crude capacity remains broadly unchanged over the period.

702: Shutting in output can be helpful for mature oil fields as it will allow pressure to rebuild and make it easier for operations to restart.

995: The global refining industry is set to undergo another major step change as it adapts to slowing oil demand growth amid the accelerating transition to clean energy technologies over the 2023 2030 forecast period.

1061: One lens through which to view refinery profitability is the relative tightness between crude and product markets.
1062: If refiners face a disparity in conditions between crude and product markets, then arguably they have three options for handling the mismatch.
1063: First, if the margin structure supports it, they can continue to pay up for crude.
1064: Second, if they have operational flexibility, refiners can draw crude inventories, which effectively contributes to tighter crude market conditions.
1065: Lastly, if margins don’t support processing crude, they can cut runs and thereby transmit weakness in product markets back to crude markets.

1072: Run cuts effectively transfer product market weakness back into crude markets.
1073: Second, the refining industry now has a greater share of merchant refineries that can respond more quickly and be operationally and financially disciplined in reacting to changes in market conditions.
